pullRequest.body:
It is currently `â„¤`-valued, but always nonnegative.

Also rename the misnamed `norm_eq_pow_val` to `norm_eq_zpow_neg_valuation`

From FLT

Closes https://github.com/ImperialCollegeLondon/FLT/issues/277

---

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ one_le_zpow_iff_right_of_lt_oneâ‚€`
`+ one_le_zpow_iff_rightâ‚€`
`+ one_lt_zpow_iff_right_of_lt_oneâ‚€`
`+ one_lt_zpow_iff_rightâ‚€`
`+ valuation_coe`
`+ valuation_coe_nonneg`
`+ valuation_inv`
`+ valuation_zpow`
`+ zpow_le_one_iff_right_of_lt_oneâ‚€`
`+ zpow_le_one_iff_rightâ‚€`
`+ zpow_lt_one_iff_right_of_lt_oneâ‚€`
`+ zpow_lt_one_iff_rightâ‚€`

<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

This PR/issue depends on:
* leanprover-community/mathlib4#20032
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

This looks good â€“Â thanks for the general cleanup work on the `Padics` files. Should we also have a version of the valuation taking values in `WithTop N`, analogous to `Padic.addValuation`? Anyway, that can be for a later PR.

One question: is there a general reason why it's better not to refer to the `Fact` section variable by name? I agree we don't usually give explicit names to instance variables, but `Fact` is obviously a special case, and it loses a few golf points to keep writing `(Fact.out : p.Prime)` in place of `hp.out`.

This looks good â€“Â thanks for the general cleanup work on the `Padics` files. Should we also have a version of the valuation taking values in `WithTop N`, analogous to `Padic.addValuation`? Anyway, that can be for a later PR.

One question: is there a general reason why it's better not to refer to the `Fact` section variable by name? I agree we don't usually give explicit names to instance variables, but `Fact` is obviously a special case, and it loses a few golf points to keep writing `(Fact.out : p.Prime)` in place of `hp.out`.
These aren't specific to p-adics, so maybe should be split off into a separate mini-PR. What is the rationale for tagging the `1 < a` lemmas as `simp`, but not the `0 < a < 1` lemmas?
I've opened #20032. For the simp tagging, I just followed what was already done in the file
It avoided having to refer to the `Fact` instance by name, but I've reverted that

pullRequest.title: refactor: make `PadicInt.valuation` `â„•`-valued

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).

This looks good â€“Â thanks for the general cleanup work on the `Padics` files. Should we also have a version of the valuation taking values in `WithTop N`, analogous to `Padic.addValuation`? Anyway, that can be for a later PR.

One question: is there a general reason why it's better not to refer to the `Fact` section variable by name? I agree we don't usually give explicit names to instance variables, but `Fact` is obviously a special case, and it loses a few golf points to keep writing `(Fact.out : p.Prime)` in place of `hp.out`.
